Simple Moving Average Plot

Source: R/ts-sma-plot.R
ts_sma_plot.Rd

This function will take in a value column and return any number n moving averages.

ts_sma_plot(
  .data,
  .sma_order = 2,
  .func = mean,
  .align = "center",
  .partial = FALSE
)

Arguments

.data

The data that you are passing, this can be either a ts object or a tibble
.sma_order

This will default to 1. This can be a vector like c(2,4,6,12)
.func

The unquoted function you want to pass, mean, median, etc
.align

This can be either "left", "center", "right"
.partial

This is a bool value of TRUE/FALSE, the default is TRUE

Value

Will invisibly return a list object.

Details

This function will accept a time series object or a tibble/data.frame. This is a simple wrapper around timetk::slidify_vec(). It uses that function to do the underlying moving average work. Since the function ts_to_tbl() is called there is no need to supply a value column. This function will only work on a single value column

It can only handle a single moving average at a time and therefore if multiple are called for, it will loop through and append data to a tibble or ts object.

Author

Steven P. Sanderson II, MPH

Examples

out <- ts_sma_plot(AirPassengers, .sma_order = c(3,6))

#> Attempting to coerce to a tibble.
#> Warning: `type_convert()` only converts columns of type 'character'.
#> - `df` has no columns of type 'character'

out$data

#> # A tibble: 288 x 5
#>    index     date_col   value sma_order sma_value
#>    <yearmon> <date>     <dbl> <fct>         <dbl>
#>  1 Jan 1949  1949-01-01   112 3               NA 
#>  2 Feb 1949  1949-02-01   118 3              121.
#>  3 Mar 1949  1949-03-01   132 3              126.
#>  4 Apr 1949  1949-04-01   129 3              127.
#>  5 May 1949  1949-05-01   121 3              128.

#>  7 Jul 1949  1949-07-01   148 3              144.
#>  8 Aug 1949  1949-08-01   148 3              144 
#>  9 Sep 1949  1949-09-01   136 3              134.
